rsbNotes.title: Ex 25:1–31:8
rsbNotes.text: 25:1–31:8 This section goes into great detail regarding the divine pattern for the place where the Lord Himself would dwell among His people. The tabernacle and its ministry are the two central features—details of the tabernacle construction, and the precise elements, manner, and persons to be employed in God’s service are carefully specified. The inauguration of the covenant had established God’s kingship over Israel. That kingship was now to be appropriately recognized by the building of a residence for God as a symbol of His royal authority over Israel.

rsbNotes.title: Ex 28:1–30:3
rsbNotes.text: 28:1–30:3 Having revealed the pattern of the earthly sanctuary (25:1–27:21), God now reveals the regulations for the priestly ministry of the sanctuary.

rsbNotes.title: Ex 29:1
rsbNotes.text: 29:1 consecrate. Or, “make them holy,” set them apart from their fellow Israelites for God’s service.

rsbNotes.title: Ex 29:2
rsbNotes.text: 29:2 bread . . . cakes . . . wafers. Three kinds of grain offering were to be presented (cf. Lev. 2:4–10).

rsbNotes.title: Ex 29:4
rsbNotes.text: 29:4 wash them with water. Aaron and his sons could not enter the tabernacle until they had been ceremonially cleansed by washing, and sacrifice had been made for them (cf. Heb. 7:26–28).

rsbNotes.title: Ex 29:5
rsbNotes.text: 29:5 take the garments. Aaron and his sons were to be clothed with sacred garments symbolic of their office. Only Aaron is anointed (and thereby authorized to act as chief priest).

rsbNotes.title: Ex 29:9
rsbNotes.text: 29:9 ordain. Lit. “fill the hand,” a Hebrew idiom for induction into office.

rsbNotes.title: Ex 29:10
rsbNotes.text: 29:10 bring the bull. Priests laid their hands on the bull calf to symbolize personal identification and substitution in this sin offering. Blood was smeared on the horns of the altar of burnt offering as for laymen, since Aaron and his sons were still unconsecrated (Lev. 4:25, 30; cf. Lev. 4:7). The remainder of the blood was poured at the bottom of the altar as for a sin offering. Certain parts were to be burned on the altar (v. 13), but the remainder was to be burned outside the camp as unclean (v. 14).

rsbNotes.title: Ex 29:15
rsbNotes.text: 29:15 one of the rams. This ram was offered as a dedicatory burnt offering (Lev. 1:3–17 note).

rsbNotes.title: Ex 29:19
rsbNotes.text: 29:19 take the other ram. The other ram was offered as a peace offering (Lev. 3:1 note).

rsbNotes.title: Ex 29:20
rsbNotes.text: 29:20 put it on the tip. The ear, hands, and feet of the priests (extremities as parts for the whole) were cleansed from impurities to consecrate for service.

rsbNotes.title: Ex 29:22
rsbNotes.text: 29:22 the right thigh. Normally part of the priest’s portion (Lev. 7:32), this was also burned in this sacrifice for the priests.

rsbNotes.title: Ex 29:24
rsbNotes.text: 29:24 wave them. The ceremonial waving symbolized their dedication as gifts to God.

rsbNotes.title: Ex 29:26
rsbNotes.text: 29:26 your portion. Moses, since he was acting as priest, received the breast and the thigh of the ram as his portion; thereafter the priests were to receive these (Lev. 7:31–32).

rsbNotes.title: Ex 29:38
rsbNotes.text: 29:38 day by day regularly. The requirements for the daily priestly offerings are reviewed (vv. 38–46). The author of Hebrews contrasts these daily sacrifices for sin (whose repetition pointed to their insufficiency) with the once-for-all sacrifice of Christ (Heb. 10:11–14).

rsbNotes.title: Ex 29:42–46
rsbNotes.text: 29:42–46 This passage states the goal of the Exodus (and of the book). God “brought them out of the land of Egypt” that He might “dwell among them” (v. 46). The covenant relationship between God and His people is fundamentally one of communion between God and man (Gen. 17:7; Ex. 6:7).

rsbNotes.title: Ex 30:1
rsbNotes.text: 30:1 an altar on which to burn incense. The altar was in front of the veil at the entrance to the Most Holy Place (v. 6). It was lit by the high priest morning and evening. The smoke that then covered the mercy seat protected the high priest from the divine presence (Lev. 16:13).
